Old news, new evidence - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2012/12/onlinedrugtoonthumb.png" />

Minimum price will have a minimum impact - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2012/12/minpricingcartoonTBthumb.jpg" />

University Challenged - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2012/12/onlineunitoon1thumb1.png" />

The Naked Truth - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2012/12/onlinenuditybancartoonKMthumb1.jpg" />

Cocaine on campus: Old news, new evidence

The University should concentrate on its support systems for drug users on campus, and stop running away from such a national issue.

Minimum price will have minimum impact

Fair enough, we have a big problem. The amount of alcohol this nation drinks is affecting people's health.

Losing faith in schools

Instead of the coalition implementing a greater number of faith schools, they should focus on raising the level of teaching in all schools across the country.

Cultured LAD

University challenged

It seems ironic that the elitists who complain about mass higher education are likely to also be the ones most opposed to these institutions gaining university status - despite present exclusion being based upon the small size of their student bodies.

Working towards the future

The government must start prioritising job creation over deficit reduction if they have any hope of getting the long term unemployed into sustainable jobs.

Flattening out the playing fields

But I believe that when it comes to education, fairness should always trump concerns about choice and personal freedoms.

The Naked Truth

We must accept, nudity is now offensive to the majority and that it should not be practised in public, often imposed on those who do not request to be exposed to it.

Sober up

In every society, there are those who don't drink and it would be nice if they were represented. It may even demonstrate to the rest of the society that you don't need alcohol to have a good time when out with your team.

You can't manufacture community spirit

The University should focus on improving Wentworth's community spirit rather than sending postgraduates to other colleges.

All or nothing in the JCRCs

The fierce competition over most college Chair positions is a healthy process that gets candidates wracking their brains for the best policies, and engages the voters to rise out of their allegedly apathetic student stupor to watch the electoral bloodbath.

Ask not what your college can do for you

Too often student politics is dismissed as isolated and extraneous to the wider community, but this is to forget the number of events made possible both on and off campus by our very own JCRCs.

War on drugs: Fighting a losing battle

This nonsensically-proclaimed 'war' is the result of decades of wilfully ignorant government policy on the criminalisation and illegalisation of various substances, generally as a reaction to popular opinion.

The downsides of an internet-free life

Free internet is on offer in plenty of public areas, accessible to all; if people wanted to use the Internet, it's not impossible.

Healthcare, you're doing it right

Given this seemingly catastrophic inequality, surely you wouldn't expect Brazil to enshrine every citizen's right to healthcare, provided by the state, as part of their constitution.

It's the test of time that matters, not the turnout

Despite the abysmal turnout, what it is important to remember is that regardless of whether you support them or not, they are here to stay.

Women Bishops: Why the Government should step in

The question is whether the opinions of a first-century writer - who, incidentally, never met Jesus - should be a legitimate basis for exemption from U.K. employment law.

NUS playing around with politics

Those with more radical views will always be drawn to political activism, but the NUS is still supposed to represent us.

Demo 2012: Marching in the wrong direction

Rather than a means of empowerment, such aims may instead further weaken both the credibility of the NUS, and the wider student movement itself (Thumbnail credit Credit: Demo2012.org)

Ted Mosby Syndrome

I've always thought university was the ideal backdrop for a love story - a wry smile across a lecture hall or reaching for the same book in the library

Remember, remember, 15th November

It's like signing for a delivery on your doorstep, unwanted, and for all you know, full of snakes

The breakup beard

We've all got our rituals for dealing with a breakup. Some girls choose to engage in a freezing threesome with Ben and Jerry; others throw themselves into their studies

The Daily Mail: lolcats with a masthead

It's clear that - thanks to the internet - market forces are transforming the Daily Mail into an altogether different beast

Rewriting History

The dangers of an ideologically driven history should be heeded, particularly by the current education secretary, Michael Gove

A Doomsday economy calls for a Doomsday tax

The essential rule of thumb that we must take into account is whether the thing we are taxing can move from our shores pretty easily. If it can, it is a bad idea

Stop the press

When was the last time you saw yesterday's paper being used to wrap up your haddock and chips?
